Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Photonic and Electronic Devices Based on Self-Assembling DNA Templates

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to develop reliable protocols for fabricating functional photonic and electronic nanostructures using bioinspired, molecular assembly methods. In one of the proposed tasks, seed nanoparticles will be selectively attached through molecular recognition to the ?DNA origami? template and fused to form the electrodes; a separate nanoparticle island will be separately attached forming a single-electron transistor. In the other major task, plasmonic bow-tie antennae will be assembled from nanoparticles, and the optically active nanoscale object will be attached in the hot spot.

The intellectual merit of the proposed project stems from the convergence of recent advances in DNA-based self-assembly methods with promising preliminary results on specific surface binding of solution-assembled complexes. These nanostructures may develop into a new class of naturally biocompatible sensors that will have transformative applications in the biomedical field.

The broader impacts are the development of alternative, cheaper (most steps are in aqueous solution) and more versatile fabrication methods for making composite bio-nano-devices. The proposal has a strongly emphasized outreach component: the PIs plan to recruit MSc students from the North Carolina Central University ? a historically black university (HBCU). The program will train the students in the unique combination of biochemical and physical methods of modern nanotechnology that are relevant for both industrial and academic careers. Disadvantaged high school students (Project SEED) will participate during the summer months to get a feel for the emerging field of nanoscience.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the project was to develop reliable protocols for fabricating functional photonic and electronic nanostructures using bioinspired, molecular assembly methods. In particular, project participants have worked on the fabrication of complex metallic nanostructures such as single-electron transistors and photonic devices by DNA templating and chemical surface patterning.  In addition, the further development of DNA nanofabrication materials and tools for future device applications were also pursued.

Photonic device: we have demonstrated specific assembly of DNA origami templates decorated with four gold seed particles (5 nm diameter); controlled silver deposition upon the seed particles such that the particles are brought within plasmonic coupling distance of one another; binding of a SERS (Surface Enhanced Raman Scattering) active organic molecule (aminobenzenethiol) onto the programmed clusters; binding of the assembled devices onto surfaces; detailed scanning electron microscopy analysis of the structures; and examination of Raman spectra using a single particle microscope. The SERS enhancements observed using our four-particle, clover-leaf antennae are sufficient to have attracted the attention of a potential industrial collaborator at BD Technologies. We are working to develop a commercially viable SERS tag using the technology prototyped during this project.

Tetrahedral origami and the development of diblock polypeptides that provide enhanced solubility for the component building blocks thus increasing production yields of the desired supramolecular complex were explored and developed. The diblock polypeptides consist of a hydrophilic domain and a DNA binding domain that act as compatibilizing agents to keep DNA origami in solution at lower divalent cation concentration that they prefer and DNA-functionalized gold nanoparticles at higher divalent cation concentration that they prefer. The diblocks enhance the solubility of each component and provide conditions under which higher assembly yields of the desired products are achieved.

By performing competitive annealing experiments, we intentionally frustrated origami scaffold folding by simultaneously using two different staple sets in order to investigate kinetic trapping of partially folded or chimeric structures. We observed the concentration and annealing conditions under which different 2400-base origami structures predominated in the assembly products. We showed that such competitive annealing experiments are an effective way of comparing the various forces involved in DNA origami folding.

In order to further explore the pathways of folding for DNA origami structures we performed chemical quenching during origami annealing. Formaldehyde was found to be an effective agent for reacting with ssDNA and inhibiting further DNA hybridization, thereby preventing further origami folding even though the temperature continued to drop below the annealing temperature. We showed that this strategy is useful in following the progression of structure formation during the origami annealing process and that it may be useful for optimizing assembly yields in future bionanofabrication schemes. 

This project involved considerable efforts in outreach to various communities of interest. The team was able to present posters at two local scientific meetings and to address visitors at the departmental open-house. On the order of 15 invited talks utilizing data generated by the project were given by the PI. Four student poster presentation were made. Five manuscripts have appeared in print and another four manuscripts are in various stages of review and revision.

The graduate and undergraduate students who worked on this project have received valuable, interdisciplinary research training. The female graduate student has joined a leadership training program at BD Technologies. The training she received as part of this ECCS project has allowed her to land a high-paying industrial job in which she will create new commercial technologies that will impact future medical diagnostic or therapeutic options for the American and global health sectors. The undergraduate students trained during this project will also be an important part of the future, nano-savvy workforce for our country and the global community.


Last Modified: 10/07/2016
Modified by: Thom Labean

In particular, project participants have worked on the fabrication of complex metallic nanostructures such as single-electron transistors and photonic devices by DNA templating and chemical surface patterning.
